segment.source: Speech recognition: converts words spoken by the user into text for form input, for text dictation, to specify an action or command, and to accomplish tasks.
segment.target: Speech recognition: converts words spoken by the user into text for form input, for text dictation, to specify an action or command, and to accomplish tasks.

segment.source: Both pre-defined grammars for free-text dictation and web search, and custom grammars authored using Speech Recognition Grammar Specification (SRGS) Version 1.0 are supported.
segment.target: Both pre-defined grammars for free-text dictation and web search, and custom grammars authored using Speech Recognition Grammar Specification (SRGS) Version 1.0 are supported.

segment.source: TTS: uses a speech synthesis engine (voice) to convert a text string into spoken words.
segment.target: TTS: uses a speech synthesis engine (voice) to convert a text string into spoken words.

segment.source: The input string can be either basic, unadorned text or more complex Speech Synthesis Markup Language (SSML).
segment.target: The input string can be either basic, unadorned text or more complex Speech Synthesis Markup Language (SSML).

segment.source: SSML provides a standard way to control characteristics of speech output, such as pronunciation, volume, pitch, rate or speed, and emphasis.
segment.target: SSML provides a standard way to control characteristics of speech output, such as pronunciation, volume, pitch, rate or speed, and emphasis.

segment.source: Note Using Cortana and customized voice commands, your app can be launched in the foreground (the app takes focus, just as if it was launched from the Start menu) or activated as a background service (Cortana retains focus but provides results from the app).

segment.source: Commands that require additional context or user input (such as sending a message to a specific contact) are best handled in a foreground app, while basic commands can be handled in Cortana through a background app.

segment.source: Constraints
segment.target: Constraints

segment.source: Constraints, or grammars, define the spoken words and phrases that can be matched by the speech recognizer.
segment.target: Constraints, or grammars, define the spoken words and phrases that can be matched by the speech recognizer.

segment.source: You can specify one of the pre-defined web service grammars or you can create a custom grammar that is installed with your app.
segment.target: You can specify one of the pre-defined web service grammars or you can create a custom grammar that is installed with your app.

segment.source: Predefined grammars
segment.target: Predefined grammars

segment.source: Predefined dictation and web-search grammars provide speech recognition for your app without requiring you to author a grammar.
segment.target: Predefined dictation and web-search grammars provide speech recognition for your app without requiring you to author a grammar.

segment.source: When using these grammars, speech recognition is performed by a remote web service and the results are returned to the device
segment.target: When using these grammars, speech recognition is performed by a remote web service and the results are returned to the device

segment.source: The default free-text dictation grammar can recognize most words and phrases that a user can say in a particular language, and is optimized to recognize short phrases.
segment.target: The default free-text dictation grammar can recognize most words and phrases that a user can say in a particular language, and is optimized to recognize short phrases.

segment.source: Free-text dictation is useful when you don't want to limit the kinds of things a user can say.
segment.target: Free-text dictation is useful when you don't want to limit the kinds of things a user can say.

segment.source: Typical uses include creating notes or dictating the content for a message.
segment.target: Typical uses include creating notes or dictating the content for a message.

segment.source: The web-search grammar, like a dictation grammar, contains a large number of words and phrases that a user might say.
segment.target: The web-search grammar, like a dictation grammar, contains a large number of words and phrases that a user might say.

segment.source: However, it is optimized to recognize terms that people typically use when searching the web.
segment.target: However, it is optimized to recognize terms that people typically use when searching the web.

segment.source: Note Because predefined dictation and web-search grammars can be large, and because they are online (not on the device), performance might not be as fast as with a custom grammar installed on the device.
segment.target: Note Because predefined dictation and web-search grammars can be large, and because they are online (not on the device), performance might not be as fast as with a custom grammar installed on the device.

segment.source: These predefined grammars can be used to recognize up to 10 seconds of speech input and require no authoring effort on your part.
segment.target: These predefined grammars can be used to recognize up to 10 seconds of speech input and require no authoring effort on your part.

segment.source: However, they do require connection to a network.
segment.target: However, they do require connection to a network.

segment.source: Custom grammars
segment.target: Custom grammars

segment.source: A custom grammar is designed and authored by you and is installed with your app.
segment.target: A custom grammar is designed and authored by you and is installed with your app.

segment.source: Speech recognition using a custom constraint is performed on the device.
segment.target: Speech recognition using a custom constraint is performed on the device.

segment.source: Programmatic list constraints provide a lightweight approach to creating simple grammars using a list of words or phrases.
segment.target: Programmatic list constraints provide a lightweight approach to creating simple grammars using a list of words or phrases.

segment.source: A list constraint works well for recognizing short, distinct phrases.
segment.target: A list constraint works well for recognizing short, distinct phrases.

segment.source: Explicitly specifying all words in a grammar also improves recognition accuracy, as the speech recognition engine must only process speech to confirm a match.
segment.target: Explicitly specifying all words in a grammar also improves recognition accuracy, as the speech recognition engine must only process speech to confirm a match.

segment.source: The list can also be programmatically updated.
segment.target: The list can also be programmatically updated.

segment.source: An SRGS grammar is a static document that, unlike a programmatic list constraint, uses the XML format defined by the SRGS Version 1.0.
segment.target: An SRGS grammar is a static document that, unlike a programmatic list constraint, uses the XML format defined by the SRGS Version 1.0.

segment.source: An SRGS grammar provides the greatest control over the speech recognition experience by letting you capture multiple semantic meanings in a single recognition.
segment.target: An SRGS grammar provides the greatest control over the speech recognition experience by letting you capture multiple semantic meanings in a single recognition.

segment.source: Here are some tips for authoring SRGS grammars:
segment.target: Here are some tips for authoring SRGS grammars:

segment.source: Keep each grammar small.
segment.target: Keep each grammar small.

segment.source: Grammars that contain fewer phrases tend to provide more accurate recognition than larger grammars that contain many phrases.
segment.target: Grammars that contain fewer phrases tend to provide more accurate recognition than larger grammars that contain many phrases.

segment.source: It's better to have several smaller grammars for specific scenarios than to have a single grammar for your entire app.
segment.target: It's better to have several smaller grammars for specific scenarios than to have a single grammar for your entire app.

segment.source: Let users know what to say for each app context and enable and disable grammars as needed.
segment.target: Let users know what to say for each app context and enable and disable grammars as needed.

segment.source: Design each grammar so users can speak a command in a variety of ways.
segment.target: Design each grammar so users can speak a command in a variety of ways.

segment.source: For example, you can use the GARBAGE rule to match speech input that your grammar does not define.
segment.target: For example, you can use the GARBAGE rule to match speech input that your grammar does not define.

segment.source: This lets users speak additional words that have no meaning to your app.
segment.target: This lets users speak additional words that have no meaning to your app.

segment.source: For example, "give me", "and", "uh", "maybe", and so on.
segment.target: For example, "give me", "and", "uh", "maybe", and so on.

segment.source: Use the sapi:subset element to help match speech input.
segment.target: Use the sapi:subset element to help match speech input.

segment.source: This is a Microsoft extension to the SRGS specification to help match partial phrases.
segment.target: This is a Microsoft extension to the SRGS specification to help match partial phrases.

segment.source: Try to avoid defining phrases in your grammar that contain only one syllable.
segment.target: Try to avoid defining phrases in your grammar that contain only one syllable.

segment.source: Recognition tends to be more accurate for phrases containing two or more syllables.
segment.target: Recognition tends to be more accurate for phrases containing two or more syllables.

segment.source: Avoid using phrases that sound similar.
segment.target: Avoid using phrases that sound similar.

segment.source: For example, phrases such as "hello", "bellow", and "fellow" can confuse the recognition engine and result in poor recognition accuracy.
segment.target: For example, phrases such as "hello", "bellow", and "fellow" can confuse the recognition engine and result in poor recognition accuracy.

segment.source: Note Which type of constraint type you use depends on the complexity of the recognition experience you want to create.
segment.target: Note Which type of constraint type you use depends on the complexity of the recognition experience you want to create.

segment.source: Any could be the best choice for a specific recognition task, and you might find uses for all types of constraints in your app.
segment.target: Any could be the best choice for a specific recognition task, and you might find uses for all types of constraints in your app.

segment.target: Text-to-speech (TTS)

segment.target: TTS generates speech output from plain text or SSML.

segment.source: Try to design prompts that are polite and encouraging.

segment.target: Consider whether you should read long strings of text.
